questions.question: How is the 'Kurtosis' of a distribution defined?
options: It is the measure of the 'tailedness' of the probability distribution
It is the measure of the symmetry of the distribution
It is the measure of the peakedness of the distribution
Both A and C

questions.question: In Bayesian Inference, what does the 'prior probability' represent?
options: The probability of the event after evidence is taken into account
The initial degree of belief in an event, before new evidence is taken into account
The probability of the evidence under the assumed hypothesis
The final degree of belief in an event after the new evidence is taken into account
questions.correct_answer: The initial degree of belief in an event, before new evidence is taken into account

questions.question: What is the primary assumption of the Poisson distribution?
options: The events are independently occurring
The mean is larger than the variance
The events occur at a constant rate
Both A and C

questions.question: Which of the following tests would be appropriate for testing the hypothesis that the means of three or more groups are equal?
options: Two-sample t-test
Chi-square test of independence
Analysis of Variance (ANOVA)
Wilcoxon signed-rank test

questions.question: In statistics, what does 'multicollinearity' refer to?
options: The correlation between multiple variables in a regression model
The correlation between the error terms in a regression model
The scenario where independent variables in a regression model are not independent
The scenario where the dependent variable in a regression model is related to the error term
questions.correct_answer: The scenario where independent variables in a regression model are not independent

questions.question: In hypothesis testing, what is a Type I error?
options: Accepting the null hypothesis when it is true
Rejecting the null hypothesis when it is false
Accepting the null hypothesis when it is false
Rejecting the null hypothesis when it is true
questions.correct_answer: Rejecting the null hypothesis when it is true

questions.question: What does 'heteroscedasticity' refer to in a regression analysis?
options: The dependent variable is correlated with the error term
The independent variables are not linearly related
The variance of the error term is not a constant
The error terms are not normally distributed
questions.correct_answer: The variance of the error term is not a constant

questions.question: What is a 'confidence interval' in statistics?
options: An interval that contains all possible values of a parameter
An interval that contains the most likely values of a parameter
An interval that contains the true population parameter a certain percentage of the time
An interval that contains the sample mean
questions.correct_answer: An interval that contains the true population parameter a certain percentage of the time

questions.question: In a survival analysis, what does the 'hazard function' represent?
options: The probability of surviving past a certain time
The probability of dying at a certain time
The instantaneous risk of the event happening at a certain time, given survival up to that time
The cumulative risk of the event happening up to a certain time
questions.correct_answer: The instantaneous risk of the event happening at a certain time, given survival up to that time

questions.question: Which distribution would you use to model the number of defects per unit in a manufacturing process?
options: Poisson Distribution
Normal Distribution
Binomial Distribution
Exponential Distribution
